comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Photographer John Degotardi Snr thoughtfully provided us with the reverse view (from the tower of St Mary's Cathedral in 1869-70?). The other side of this sawmill can be seen middle right - artsearch.nga.gov.au/Detail-LRG.cfm?View=LRG&IRN=1278... . And he also provided a closer photo of St George's - artsearch.nga.gov.au/Detail-LRG.cfm?IRN=127828&View=LRG

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: Thanks again to all your comments at the Archives Outside blog. The general consensus is Woolloomooloo Bay!

comment.author: 47201412@N02
32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet]  Terrific find. 1864 it is (before the Cathedral fire - the gothic arch must have been showing due to the extensions under way?).

My thoughts are those gents are too smartly dressed for boat builders at work.  Two of them have unusual hats on, with what looks like mosquito netting gathered at the back.  The children behind look typically bored.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
And you know why it's called a 'barque'?

'cos of all the ol' sea dogs on board . . .

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/people/beachcomberaustralia/] Perhaps your're right - they could be wealthy clients come to commission a pleasure yacht from the master boatbuilder. There's a man lurking in the background that could be one of the workers.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Better image of the Pugin School / Chapter Hall (it's his bicentenary in 2012) - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/album/ItemViewer.aspx?itemid=823409&am... (from the Pickering 1872 Album - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=442753)

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
It would seem our 1864 date was correct -
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/8579018794/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: There is an engraved view from across the bay of the new wharf published in the Illustrated Sydney News of 15/10/1864, p.8 and an interesting blurb on p.9 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/63512125 (you have to go back a page for the illustration, but it's worth it!). Which might suggest the reason for this photograph - a record of the new wharf for the relevant Government departments, as Harvey Shore's book suggests.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
